Thanks for the critique; I REALLY appreciate feedback. If anyone else feels 
like posting their opinion of my stuff, I'd welcome it.

Now: as for what DPH said--

>A couple of problems I noticed, though.

>One early scenario ended as soon as I defeated the last villain and I
>did not get a chance to clean up on the gold and silver.

This is intentional. If you don't put in an exit, it will automatically 
advance you. I did this to blend the first two levels, and to be a bit 
tricky. Creel is slow enough that you can avoid him at first, and kill him 
when you have all the treasure.

>The forest was a little tight for my archmage to walk through (I had
>to summon an image of an elf to help me out), but that was probably
>the point.

Yes. The enemies are wimps in the Northern Forest; navigation was supposed 
to be the major concern. I tried it with a cleric as a test--hard but 
doable. With just blobs, it's impossible, but that's not a viable team 
anywhere.

>Man, I love the extra large space to walk around for each scenario.
>If my archmage could not run so fast, it would make the some
>scenarios with generators interesting.

Yeah, Tactics is a nasty one if you don't have an archmage (chain lightning, 
summon elemental) or an archer (exploding bolt). The main problem with these 
levels is computer speed... my antique freezes up for several minutes when I 
do a massive chain lightning. Speaking of Tactics, did anyone understand the 
Lord Malrac reference, or am I wasting my time?

>Plotwise, it makes sense.

I hope so. I didn't put TOO much thought into it, or else it would have 
turned into a bizarre Warcraft deal, and I think the emphasis of Gladiator 
whould be solving levels, not figuring out the story. Still, a good plot is 
nice. I wish the Level 61 that came with the game functioned, as that seemed 
to have a good plot.

>The forest was a bit tight fit for getting through with an archmage.

Teleport much?

>Having my teleporter marker blocked in the stairs and the labryinth
>was a little annoying.

Yeah. I found it a lot easier to just be an archer or soldier in the 
labyrinth, and a ghost (to finish) on the stairs.

>I had to go back through twice on some levels because I missed an
>exit door (I got stuck and couldn't get to higher scenario numbers.  >Of 
>course, I missed exits on the normal levels too).

Did you find the secret levels? The major challenge is finding Subterranea 
without going to the Garden of Golden Apples. You really need to keep your 
eyes open for that one.

>How did you get that little trick where your NPCs die and
>automatically lose?

Level options. Hit asterisk on the scenario editor.

>Quality-wise:  you must have spent weeks designing the Labryinth and
>the stairs.  Other scenarios show that you spent time designing them.

Believe it or not, I did the labyrinth in two days, using a photograph of a 
mosaic which depicted the layout of the actual Labyrinth at Knossos. Fun. 
All the names are from the myths of Theseus and the Minotaur too. Of course, 
I had to revise it later...

The stairs were a chore. It took me forever to figure out what I was going 
to do for "up" stairs to make them look different from "down" stairs. I'm 
still not happy with them the way they look, but I didn't want to mess with 
the tiles. What did everyone think of my altered columns? I thought they 
turned out well.

>Hmm.  I liked your 'isolation' level a lot and it gave me ideas on
>what not to do and what to do when designing such a level.

Which level was that?

>Overall, it was really enjoyable and playable.  Excellent work.

Thank you.
